key_points: President Biden signed the $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan into law on March 11, initiating a third round of stimulus checks.
The $1,400 stimulus checks are part of a broader pandemic relief effort that includes aid to state and local governments, unemployment insurance, and funds for vaccine distribution.
Eligibility for the full $1,400 check includes adults who earned $75,000 or less, married couples earning $150,000 or less, and heads of household earning $112,500 or less.
Eligibility phases out for higher earners, with no checks for adults earning more than $80,000, married couples over $160,000, and heads of household over $120,000.
Each dependent also qualifies for an additional $1,400, without a cap, based on guardian income.
The package passed strictly along party lines in both the House and Senate, with Republicans unanimously opposing it.
The legislation was navigated through Congress using the budget reconciliation process, requiring a simple majority vote.
Direct deposit payments began arriving in bank accounts shortly after the law was signed, with some families already receiving funds.
Paper checks and Economic Impact Payment (EIP) cards will be mailed to those not receiving direct deposits, potentially taking longer to arrive.
The IRS provides a 'Get My Payment' tool for individuals to check the status of their stimulus check.
